newsitem.title: INDIA: India call steady, gilts seen quiet before auction.
newsitem.headline: India call steady, gilts seen quiet before auction.

text.p: Indian call money was quoted in the 0.25-0.75 percent range in early Tuesday trade unchanged from Monday's close as good liquidity and poor demand persisted, dealers said.
They said the call money market remained easy as funds supply with banks was good.
Call money rates have been at the current level for the last three weeks as banks are flush with funds.
A state government loan auction on Wednesday could drain some lqiudity away from banks and push rates up slightly, some dealers said.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) auctions 25 billion rupees of 13.05 percent 10-year state government bonds on April 30 and dealers expect bids to exceed the target amount.
"We think there will be bids for about 50 billion rupees, given the current liquidity and we expect the RBI to accept bids for about 40 billion," said a dealer at a state-run bank.
"This may push rates up a bit but we don't see them going up much beyond 2.0 percent as liquidity remains good," he added.
Dealers said they expected trade in government securities to remain on a low key on Tuesday ahead of Wednesday's auction.
"Prices will be largely steady in moderate trade today," said a dealer. "Market players will take positions after the auction tomorrow."
